item.title: Marvel Snap Back Online in the US as Developer Promises New Publisher
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/marvel-snap-back-online-dev-says-new-publisher

Card battler Marvel Snap has come back online in the US following an outage related to the shutdown of TikTok, and developer Second Dinner has promised changes in the future to avoid a repeat of the downtime.

The game was taken offline over the weekend after seemingly being caught up in a TikTok ban, which was rendered temporary when now-President Trump declared a temporary reprieve of 75 days for the social media platform. Second Dinner said the outage was "a surprise" and that it "wasn't planned".

In a post shared on social media platform X today, Second Dinner confirmed the app was back online in the US, although it still doesn't seem to be available to download from mobile app stores.

In its post, Second Dinner says that in order "to make sure this NEVER happens again", the studio is "working to bring more services in-house and partner with a new publisher".

As a reminder, the game's current publisher is Nuverse, a gaming-related subsidiary of TikTok owner ByteDance. Last year, ByteDance reportedly expressed interest in selling off its gaming assets, which would naturally include Nuverse.

At time of writing, in-app purchases are apparently still down within Marvel Snap, but you can make purchases on the web shop. Second Dinner has previously stated that it's "committed to ensuring that all players are compensated for their lost time" due to the outage.

If you're not familiar with Marvel Snap, it's a competitive card game currently available across PC and mobile devices. The game is described by its devs as a "fast-paced collectible card game that reimagines the genre with innovative mechanics".

In case you're wondering, Marvel Snap's service was unaffected outside the US, so if you're based in Europe or anywhere else where ByteDance's operations aren't restricted, you should still be able to log in and play with no issues.

Marvel Snap is available right now on PC, and it's usually available on mobile devices as well, although reports suggest it's not downloadable on those storefronts right now. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Sony and NCSoft Reportedly Cancel Unannounced Horizon MMO
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/horizon-mmo-canceled-report

An MMORPG based on Sony and Guerrilla Games' successful IP Horizon has apparently been canceled. The project was reportedly a collaboration between Sony and Guild Wars studio NCSoft.

Bear with me on this one. Back in 2023, Sony and NCSoft announced a "strategic partnership", and that partnership was reported to include a Horizon MMO, with leaker Kurakasis pointing to job listings for something called "Project H" (also "Project Skyline") in December that same year.

Now, however, Korean publication MTN (via Eurogamer) has reported that Project H has been canceled following a project review at NCSoft, along with several other titles in development at the company.

Of course, all of this should be taken with a pinch of salt, because Sony and NCSoft never officially announced the Horizon MMO in question, so naturally, it also hasn't officially been canceled.

However, cancelling such a project would fit in with what appears to be a wider retreat from the live service market on Sony's part. Earlier this week, the company canceled two live service games in development at Bluepoint and Bend, with the former reportedly being a God of War spinoff.

The retreat is likely inspired by the colossal failure of hero shooter Concord, which was shut down just two weeks after it launched last year. The game's developer would go on to be closed down by Sony, along with Neon Koi, previously known as Savage Game Studios.

It's also worth noting that assuming this MMO was actually in development, it's probably not the Horizon multiplayer game announced back in December 2022, as that's in development at Guerrilla itself rather than a third-party studio (although that could well end up being canceled too).

As for what's next for the Horizon series, while a new mainline game hasn't yet been announced, a live-action movie based on the property is currently in the works, along with one based on Helldivers 2.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
